thread.title: How post-Brexit Premier League visa proposals could affect Newcastle United's transfer business

author: Chris Waugh
title: How post-Brexit Premier League visa proposals could affect Newcastle United's transfer business

Newcastle United would have been able to sign Marlon Santos this summer, had work-permit proposals put forward by the Premier League for post-Brexit already been in place.
Rafa Benitez identified the Barcelona defender - who is now wanted by clubs in Germany and Italy - as a potential replacement for Florian Lejeune, who is out for the majority of the season with knee-ligament damage.
A £1.5million loan deal for the 22-year-old centre-back was even agreed in principle, only for the transfer to fall through due to the fact Marlon did not automatically meet the criteria for being awarded a work permit.
The Brazilian has yet to earn a senior cap and, given he was not guaranteed to earn more than the average Premier League wage and was not going to be an automatic starter for United, the Football Association (FA) would not hand United their Governing Body Endorsement (GBE) - something which is effectively the FA’s approval for an overseas player outside of the European Union being qualified to work in this country.
A GBE is awarded on a points-based system, which includes criteria such as transfer fee, international caps, wages and their country’s FIFA ranking.
Newcastle did sign four players from outside the EU, but two of those - Ki Sung-yueng and Kenedy - already had British work permits, while Federico Fernandez has both an Argentine and an Italian passport.
Yoshinori Muto, meanwhile, only completed his £9.5m move from Mainz once Newcastle received a GBE from the FA - with the Japan international failing to automatically meet the selection criteria. Read More What happens next with Marlon Santos move: Explaining the work permit rules
Interestingly, however, a report in The Times claims that the Premier League is pushing for any foreign player - be they from the EU or further afield - with a contract and who has been included in a 25-man top-flight squad to be eligible for a British work permit post-Brexit.
If such a ruling had been in place during the summer transfer window, then Muto would have signed without the need for a visa hearing - while Marlon’s loan signing from Barcelona would not have been thwarted by work-permit issues.
Yet the Premier League and the FA have reportedly registered “serious differences” in their visions for how football visas would be awarded to foreign players once the United Kingdom leaves the EU on March 29, 2019.
While top-flight chairmen fear the removal of free movement for EU citizens post-Brexit will prevent English clubs signing the best talent from the Continent - the likes of Ayoze Perez, Florian Lejeune and Moussa Sissoko would not have automatically qualified for visas when Newcastle first signed them had they been from outside of Europe, for example - the FA reportedly wants to increase the opportunities afforded to English players by restricting the ability for “journeymen” foreign imports to arrive. Read More How Premier League transfer deadline day could move again, with some clubs unhappy with early finish
Essentially the Premier League want the GBE system to be abandoned and for top-flight footballers to be handed what would essentially be an automatic visa for any player who has been awarded a contract and a place in the squad by a Premier League club.
According to The Times, the Premier League and the FA are still “poles apart” on how work permits should be awarded post-Brexit. Like us on Facebook
